results.title: The Baby Boomers' Picture Show
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, ABC-TV (Australia) and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Inspired by the book “Baby Boomers” by Helen Townsend, “The Baby Boomers’ Picture Show” re-creates the sensations, the thrills and the horrors of growing up in Australia in the 1950’s and 1960’s.

results.title: To Absent Friends
results.creator_credit: Ronnie Taylor, Paul Humfress and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This innovative documentary looks at the creation of the largest scale holographic project ever undertaken. Paula Dawson, the creator, is one of the world’s leading holographic artists and an important pioneer in this field. Inspired partly by Vladimir Nabokov’s book “Transparent things”, this work ” To absent friends” uses the central theme of memory through objects and allows the viewer to stand outside time and reflect on the past, or mirror. Paula’s installation was selected as one of forty works shown at Artec‘89, a high tech international art exhibition and competition, the first international Biennale in Nagoya, Japan. The three main holograms were exhibited and went on to become joint winners of the Grand Prix ‘89. This film presents the only opportunity to view the entire installation and to meet the artist who created it.

results.title: The Artist, the Peasant = L'artista, Il Contadino
results.creator_credit: Franco Di Chiera and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Artist Giuseppe Mercuri dreamed of emigrating to Australia with his family in the 1950’s but was refused entry on account of his Communist Party membership and only now has he been allowed entry to visit the country of his dreams. His work captures the reflective nature of the people and lifestyle of Calabria, the area in which he was born. In this film his nephew, Franco di Chiera has documented faithfully Mercuri’s life from the hardships of his youth through the years of creative achievement and finally to his long awaited trip to Australia which meant the fulfilment of a lifetime dream.

results.title: Rolf Harris: How to Draw Fun Cartoons
results.brief_description: Yes, it’s the distinctive cartoons, drawings and humour of the unstoppable Rolf Harris and it’s Rolf Harris in person taking you through your very own “learn to draw” lesson. “You can draw”, says Rolf Harris. “We all can. It’s just a matter of knowing that you can draw your way”. How to draw fun cartoons, will give you as much pleasure watching as it will when you try out Rolf’s methods for yourself. Don’t say “I can’t draw” anymore, let Rolf Harris show you how.

results.title: A Dangerous life
results.creator_credit: R. Markowitz, Hal McElroy and McElroy & McElroy
results.brief_description: Tells the story of the four day revolution in the Philippines. Told through the eyes of a television reporter and photojournalist, it backgrounds the struggle that led to the 1986 revolution which saw Aquino become president succeeding the ousted Ferdinand Marcos.

results.title: Skippy the Bush Kangaroo
results.creator_credit: Max Varnel, Bob Austin, John McCallum, Lee Robinson and Norfolk International Pictures
results.brief_description: Features two episodes of the television series. “Double trouble” looks at a rival who is trying to take control of the Waratah National Park; “Chicken” is about Skippy being poisoned by a local farmer who holds a grudge against the head ranger.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Max Varnel, Bob Austin, John McCallum, Lee Robinson and Norfolk International Pictures

results.title: Play School. Special; Concert
results.brief_description: Appearing in the “Play school special” are eight well-loved Play school presenters: Benita Collings, Merridy Eastman, John Hamblin, Noni Hazelhurst, Jennifer Ludlum, Philip Quast, Don Spencer and John Waters. Favourite songs include ‘Old Macdonald’, ‘Baa baa black sheep’, ‘The paper song’, ‘There’s a bear in there’ and many more. Some of the stories are ‘Harry the dirty dog’, ‘There was a princess’ and ‘The hole’. Benita Collings and John Hamblin perform in a Play School concert. The audience joins in with the words and actions of popular Play school songs. Among them are ‘I’m a little teapot’ and ‘Bananas in pyjamas’.

results.title: Wharfies: A History of the Waterside Worker's Federation
results.brief_description: Wharfies traces the history of the Australian Waterside Workers Federation from its foundation in 1902, under Billy Hughes, to the present day. Made in the tradition of the Waterside Workers Film Unit of the 1950s, “Wharfies” covers important historical events including industrial milestones, political crises and the stories of the men themselves. This film is pieced together through dramatised sequences, interviews with veteran wharfies and rare archival footage. Cartoons, news clippings and old photographs all help to tell the story.

results.title: Soldier settlers
results.brief_description: Portrays the progress made since 1945 in the establishment of ex-servicemen from World War II on Victorian land. The division of large estates, the development of existing pastures, the clearing of scrub country and the construction of irrigation channels are seen on representative farms throughout the state. Fruit growing, the dried fruit industry, wheat cultivation and sheep raising, plus dry and irrigated dairying are shown, in addition to the single-unit farm system.

results.title: Land Bilong Islanders
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Sharon Connolly, Channel 4, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Yarra Bank Films
results.brief_description: Murray Island, a tiny speck in the Coral Sea, on the northernmost fringe of Australia’s Great Barrier Reef is one of the most beautiful and isolated places in Australia, if not the world. However, Murray Island, or Mer as it is called by the Merlam people, is the centre of a legal battle that questions the very basis of European settlement in Australia. Three Murray Islanders have taken the Queensland and Australian Governments to court claiming that islanders, not the State, own island land. They say that in Merlam law and custom their families had, since time immemorial, distinct rights to the land and to adjoining seabeds and reefs. Islanders argue that those rights continued after the island was annexed to the then British Colony of Queensland.
